{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2984975,"name":"Srinivas Deva","username":"srinivasdeva","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b9e5f3/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T05:37:24.762Z","cooked":"

Hello,

I have an arm mechanism controlled by a NEO that is connected to a SparkMax in brushless mode. I wanted to use a mag encoder with the SparkMax, but based on my research it is not possible to connect a PWM input to the data port on the device. Therefore, I was wondering if I can use a somewhat ‚Äúhacky‚Äù solution and take advantage of the SparkMax API‚Äôs getEncoder().setPosition() method. Since I am able to retrieve absolute encoder values from the code, I can override the NEO‚Äôs integrated encoder position values using this method constantly and replace them with the absolute encoder readings I get from the PWM input to the rio. I understand that the setPosition method is intended to be used to reset the integrated encoder position, but will continuously overriding the integrated encoder values allow me to use the SparkMax‚Äôs SmartMotion or position control? Thanks in advance.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-01-04T05:37:24.762Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":784,"reads":318,"readers_count":317,"score":3988.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398659,"topic_slug":"can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api","display_username":"Srinivas Deva","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/need-help-with-pid-controller/494936/2","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Need help with pid controller","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49088,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api/398659/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2984977,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T05:55:08.503Z","cooked":"

Why exactly do you want to do this? Perhaps I‚Äôm just missing something.

Using an external encoded should definitely be possible, for closed-loop position/velocity control at least, though you shouldn‚Äôt need to go about it that way. We‚Äôd need to know specifically what mag encoder you want to use, but I suspect it‚Äôs not actually a PWM signal (again, could be wrong).

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-01-04T05:55:08.503Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":310,"readers_count":309,"score":92.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":398659,"topic_slug":"can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api/398659/2","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985021,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T15:45:21.201Z","cooked":"
srinivasdeva:

will continuously overriding the integrated encoder values allow me to use the SparkMax‚Äôs SmartMotion or position control?

The primary purpose of the integrated encoder is to control commutation of the motor. Messing with it is likely to lead to a bad day.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-01-04T15:45:21.201Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":252,"readers_count":251,"score":95.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398659,"topic_slug":"can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api/398659/4","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985029,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T16:20:27.941Z","cooked":"

I would avoid it. Setting the encoder value once while everything is relatively motionless is one thing. Trying to do it constantly while things are in motion will lead to inaccuracies due to backlash in your mechanical system and communication latency.

Also - be wary of saturating the can bus. We were surprised to find that if you set the PID values on each loop for 4 spark maxes, the can bus utilization jumped from 62% up to 95%.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-01-04T16:20:27.941Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":233,"readers_count":232,"score":106.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398659,"topic_slug":"can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api/398659/5","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985030,"name":"David Lame","username":"David_Lame","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/51bf81/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T16:26:37.840Z","cooked":"

I may not understand what you are trying to do, but I‚Äôll take a shot.

I think what you are trying to do is to move your arm to an absolute position, as measured by your absolute encoder. Is that correct?

Assuming it is ‚Ä¶

I think the best way to do that would be to take a single measurement of the absolute encoder, and call setposition() using that measurement. In theory, after that point, your absolute and relative positions really ought to be the same. (Of course, you have to transform the reading into the appropriate units and all that stuff.)

What you are proposing would be to continuously update the relative encoder on the spark Max using the absolute encoder‚Äôs measurement. While that would work, I wouldn‚Äôt trust that to play nice with the spark Max position controls.

There really shouldn‚Äôt be any need for continuous updates after an initial position is established. If there is something about your setup that makes it necessary, I would instead constantly compare the absolute encoder value with the relative (spark Max) value, and only update when the values diverge.

Summary:. If I understand what you want to do, it ought to work, but it shouldn‚Äôt be necessary, and it might confuse the spark Max software.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-01-04T16:26:37.840Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":218,"readers_count":217,"score":138.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398659,"topic_slug":"can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api","display_username":"David Lame","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24723,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api/398659/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985031,"name":"ahartnet","username":"ahartnet","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ahartnet/{size}/5249_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T16:27:30.500Z","cooked":"

I think similar to how some teams do swerve, you should just use the absolute encoder for more or less your initial loop, but use the integrated incremental encoder for setting position beyond that. You should be able to calculate how many rotations should be equal to one degree of rotations on the arm as a starting point and then verify/adjust with your real arm. You just need the absolute encoder on start up to set the relation between 0 on the integrated encoder and the actual arm position.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-01-04T16:27:30.500Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":72.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398659,"topic_slug":"can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api","display_username":"ahartnet","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15473,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5414 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api/398659/7","custom_user_title":"5414 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985038,"name":"Srinivas Deva","username":"srinivasdeva","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b9e5f3/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T16:50:50.074Z","cooked":"
ahartnet:

I think similar to how some teams do swerve, you should just use the absolute encoder for more or less your initial loop, but use the integrated incremental encoder for setting position beyond that. You should be able to calculate how many rotations should be e

Yeah I think this would be the best solution. However, I am worried that the integrated encoder will not offer enough resolution since it‚Äôs 42 CPR. I will have to check my gearing and the encoder values to see if this is enough to do some position control. Thanks

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-01-04T16:50:50.074Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":175,"readers_count":174,"score":55.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":398659,"topic_slug":"can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api","display_username":"Srinivas Deva","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49088,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api/398659/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985042,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T17:02:08.582Z","cooked":"
srinivasdeva:

Yeah I think this would be the best solution. However, I am worried that the integrated encoder will not offer enough resolution since it‚Äôs 42 CPR.

FYI - we used the described technique (zero with the absolute encoder, position with the integrated, incremental encoder) for all of our mechanisms (and drive train) in 2019 and 2020 without issue. Behind a gearbox, each step corresponds to a tiny amount of mechanism travel. We had no issues with accuracy.

If you still want to use the absolute encoder for primary feedback, I‚Äôll defer to others - but my impression is that it‚Äôs a challenge to do through the Spark Max (for reasons I don‚Äôt fully understand). You can run the encoder signal back to the Rio though and run your PID on the Rio - commanding the Spark Max in open-loop mode. It‚Äôs not as easy (and doesn‚Äôt run as fast), but teams have done it afaik.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2022-01-04T17:02:08.582Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":173,"readers_count":172,"score":69.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398659,"topic_slug":"can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-you-override-the-built-in-neo-encoder-values-with-absolute-encoder-values-using-sparkmax-api/398659/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985082,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-04T18:48:30.394Z","cooked":"
nuclearnerd:

It‚Äôs not as easy (and doesn‚Äôt run as fast)

1 kHz loop frequencies are kind of a meme, tbh. 200 Hz was good enough for a really light flywheel with on-RIO control, in 3512‚Äôs experience. Slower accelerating systems like elevators or drivetrains can get away with even lower frequencies. Higher frequencies in a discrete system more closely approximate a continuous system, which minimizes the sample delay (i.e., how long the control input is held constant between updates).

Measurement latency is what mainly determines how aggressive your controller gains can be without inducing oscillation. The optimal no-delay and delay-compensated gains are generally an order of magnitude different.

Screenshot_20220104_1104261110√ó984 112 KB

_from ‚ÄúTime delay compensation‚Äù section in appendix B of https://file.tavsys.net/control/controls-engineering-in-frc.pdf_
Plots generated by:
_https://github.com/calcmogul/controls-engineering-in-frc/blob/main/appendices/linear-quadratic-regulator/drivetrain_time_delay.py_
_https://github.com/calcmogul/controls-engineering-in-frc/blob/main/appendices/linear-quadratic-regulator/flywheel_time_delay.py_

Filtering and CAN status frame delay (if you use motor controller sensors over CAN and RIO-side controls) are the main drivers for that. Measurement latency has less of an effect for systems that accelerate slower.

Motor controllers‚Äôs default filtering settings add the equivalent of 30-80 ms of delay to velocity measurements [1]. To minimize filtering delay, use the minimum amount of filtering you can get away with.

CAN status frames arrive every 20 ms asynchronously, so the delay can be anywhere from 0 ms to 20 ms. Some frames can be sent more often without the payload getting zeroed out due to conflicts, but beware of bus utilization.

The main reason to use on-motor-controller sensors and PID, in my opinion, is to simplify wiring. The software implementation with RIO-only controls tends to be simpler than on-motor-controller controls because large blocks of motor controller configuration code aren‚Äôt needed.

import com.revrobotics.CANSparkMax;
import edu.wpi.first.math.PIDController;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.TimedRobot;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Encoder;

public class Robot extends TimedRobot {
  private Encoder encoder = new Encoder(1, 2);
  private static final kDistancePerPulse = ...;

  private CANSparkMax motor = new CANSparkMax(0);

  private static final kP = ...;
  private PIDController controller = new PIDController(kP, 0.0, 0.0, 0.01);

  public Robot() {
    encoder.SetDistancePerPulse(kVelocityPerPulse);

    // Run controller every 10 ms
    addPeriodic(() -> {
      motor.setVoltage(controller.calculate(encoder.getRate()));
    }, 0.01);
  }

  @Override
  public teleopPeriodic() {
    // Set the controller setpoint here
  }
}

A SimpleMotorFeedforward could be added as well, which works with either on-RIO or on-motor-controller control.

[1] sysid/sysid-application/src/main/native/include/sysid/analysis/FeedbackControllerPreset.h at main ¬∑ wpilibsuite/sysid ¬∑ GitHub
